conclusion: I'll analyze this problem by examining the relationship between velocity squared versus displacement and how it relates to acceleration.
The graph shows v² (square of velocity) on the y-axis versus x (displacement) on the x-axis. Both cars start at the same position and move in the same direction with uniform acceleration.
For uniformly accelerated motion, we can use: v² = v₀² + 2ax, where v is the final velocity, v₀ is the initial velocity, a is acceleration, and x is displacement.

Both lines are straight, which confirms uniform acceleration (constant a). Line A has a steeper slope than line B. Line A starts at v² = 0 (origin). Line B starts at v² = 1, meaning car B has an initial velocity.

premise: From v² = v₀² + 2ax, we can see that the slope of the v²-x graph is equal to 2a.

Car A has the greater acceleration (2 m/s²) compared to Car B (1 m/s²). This is because the slope of line A is steeper than the slope of line B on the v²-x graph, and acceleration is directly proportional to the slope of this graph.
conclusion: Car A has the greater acceleration.
